**Gel Electrophoresis**

*TAE has a lower buffering capacity (c.f. TBE or TPE) -- if buffer
becomes exhausted then bromophenol blue will turn yellow (in acidic
anodic portion of gel). Linear dsDNA migrates faster through TAE c.f.
TBE (c. 10 %) -- therefore TAE is better for resolving high-MW gDNA, TBE
is better for resolving low-MW DNAs. TAE is better for resolving
supercoiled DNA.*

*For good looking gels, run maxigels @ 40V × 24 hrs (do NOT exceed this
voltage!)*

**Agarose gel (1 %)**

*This recipe is sufficient for a gel (and buffer) for a midi tray.*

i\) make 1L of TAE (× 1)[^1]

ii\) mix 1.2 g agarose with 60 ml TAE (× 1) in 500 ml screw-top bottle

weigh bottle and note weight

iii\) microwave (e.g. 1 min 50 s)

check to see if agarose dissolved (use oven gloves)

microwave again (e.g. 30 -- 60 s) and repeat prn until dissolved

iv\) weigh bottle and top up to original weight with dH~2~O[^2]

v\) add 60 ml TAE (× 1)[^3]

vi\) add c. 5 μl of EtBr (stock solution = 10 mg ml^--1^)[^4]

**Pour gel**

i\) tape ends shut with masking tape

add combs

ensure tray is level on spirit level base

ii\) pour in agarose mixture

remove bubbles with pipette tip

iii\) allow to set @ RT° × 30 -- 60 mins (or quicker @ 4°)

iv\) wrap in cling-film and store @ 4° overnight if not for immediate
use

**Set up apparatus**

i\) remove masking tape

ensure correct orientation (DNA runs NEG to POS)

ii\) pour in enough TAE (× 1) to cover gel and provide c. 4 mm layer on
top

carefully remove combs

iii\) mix PCR products with loading dye[^5] (e.g. 2 μl dye for each 20
μl of PCR product)

this can be done with repeat pipette (and same tip) followed by short
spin to 1000 rpm to mix

iv\) load samples into gel avoiding bubbles (e.g. 18 μl in each lane)

load ladder (e.g. 5 μl of GeneRuler)

v\) switch on (e.g. 80 V × 300 mA × 60 mins)[^6]

ensure electrodes are bubbling

check periodically to see where dye-front is

**Photograph gel**

i\) chose Kodak programme

ensure set up for correct gel size (e.g. 13 × 17 cm for midi gel) and
exposure time (e.g. 3.5 s)

ii\) lay gel on slab and cover borders with plastic mats

place camera hood over gel

iii\) switch on UV light

take picture

switch off UV light when shutter sounds[^7]

iv\) process picture (invert and rotate)

export to memory stick

**Harvest DNA**

i\) identify bands of interest on photograph above

ii\) under direct visualisation in UV light, cut round bands with
scalpel

minimise total length of time exposed to UV light

iii\) collect gel in Eppendorf tubes and note weight

iv\) extract nucleic acid with appropriate kit

[^1]: use the same batch of TAE (× 1) for the gel and the buffer (or
    else will get blurred bands)

[^2]: this step replaces water lost through evaporation during
    microwaving; alternatively zero balance when first weighed and then
    top back up to zero

[^3]: this step helps the mixture to cool

[^4]: this should *just* tint the mixture but no more

[^5]: usually bromophenol blue / xylene cyanol but may be another dye if
    PCR product is very small

[^6]: when programming the power pack you do not have to enter a time so
    long as you will be able to check on it regularly

[^7]: minimise time of expose to UV light as this will bleach EtBr
